TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine, smectitic, frigid Typic Haplustalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Spud very stony loam, on a west facing slightly convex lower mountainside with a slope  of 25 percent in a mixed conifer woodland at 8,200 feet elevation.  When described, the soil was nearly dry throughout.  (Colors are for dry soils unless otherwise noted.)
0--2 to 0 inches; decomposing forest litter.
A1--0 to 5 inches; dark gray (N 4/) very stony loam, black (N 2/) moist; moderate fine and very fine granular structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many fine, very fine, medium and coarse roots; many fine and very fine interstitial pores; 15 percent stones, 30 percent cobbles, and 5 percent pebbles; slightly acid; clear smooth boundary.  (5 to 8 inches thick)
A21--5 to 11 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) very stony loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; very weak medium subangular blocky structure parting to moderate fine and medium granules; soft, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many fine, very fine, medium and coarse roots; many fine, medium and coarse tubular pores; 15 percent stones, 20 percent cobbles, and 5 percent pebbles; slightly acid; clear wavy boundary.  (0 to 7 inches thick)
A22--11 to 22 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) very stony loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak medium and coarse subangular blocky structure parting to strong medium and coarse granules; hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many fine, very fine, medium and coarse roots; many fine, medium and coarse tubular pores; 10 percent stones, 20 percent cobbles, and 5 percent pebbles; slightly acid; clear wavy boundary.  (6 to 12 inches thick)
B&A--22 to 26 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/4) clay loam, 70 percent dark brown (7.5YR 4/4) and 30 percent brown (7.5YR 5/4) moist; weak and moderate medium and coarse subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, sticky and plastic; many tubular pores; few and common thin clay films on faces of peds and in pores of B material; 5 percent stones, 6 percent cobbles, and 3 percent pebbles; slightly acid; clear wavy boundary.  (0 to 5 inches thick)
B21t--26 to 36 inches; reddish brown (5YR 5/4) clay, reddish brown (5YR 4/4) moist; strong medium and coarse subangular blocky structure; very hard, very firm, very sticky and very plastic; common fine, very fine, and coarse and many medium roots; many fine, very fine, and common coarse tubular pores; many thin clay films on faces of peds and in pores; few medium pockets of A2 material in upper part; 8 percent stones, 3 percent cobbles, and 3 percent pebbles; neutral; gradual wavy boundary.  (8 to 12 inches thick)
B22t--36 to 49 inches; reddish brown (5YR 5/4) clay, reddish brown (5YR 4/4) moist; strong medium and coarse subangular blocky structure; very hard, very firm, very sticky and very plastic; few fine and very fine, common medium and coarse roots; many fine and very fine tubular pores; many thin and few moderately thick clay films on faces of peds; 8 percent stones, 3 percent cobbles, and 3 percent pebbles; neutral; gradual wavy boundary.  (10 to 14 inches thick)
B23t--49 to 56 inches; reddish brown (5YR 5/4) stony clay loam, reddish brown (5YR 4/4) moist; strong coarse subangular blocky structure; very hard, very firm, very sticky and very plastic; common fine and medium roots; many fine tubular pores; many thin and very few moderately thick clay films on faces of peds; 8 percent stones, 4 percent cobbles, and 3 percent pebbles; neutral; gradual wavy boundary.  (7 to 13 inches thick)
B24t--56 to 68 inches; reddish brown (5YR 5/4) stony clay loam, reddish brown (5YR 4/4) moist; moderate coarse subangular blocky structure; very hard, firm, sticky and plastic; many fine, very fine, medium and coarse roots; many fine and very fine tubular pores; few and common thin clay films, many medium black root channels, and many medium black blotches on faces of peds; 8 percent stones, 4 percent cobbles, and 3 percent pebbles; neutral; diffused irregular boundary.  (0 to 12 inches thick)
B3--68 to 78 inches; reddish brown (5YR 5/4) very stony sandy clay loam, reddish brown (5YR 4/4) moist; moderate coarse subangular blocky structure; very hard, firm, slightly sticky and plastic; many fine and very fine tubular pores; few thin clay films and many medium black blotches on faces of peds; 20 percent stones, 15 percent cobbles, and 5 percent pebbles; neutral.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Mora County, New Mexico; about 5 1/2 miles northwest of Ocate via Black Lake road; 20 feet east of mountain road in the NW1/4 section 2, T.23N., R.17E., in the Mora Land Grant.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Thickness of the solum is typically greater than 60 inches but ranges from 40 to greater than 60 inches.  The solum is neutral or slightly acid in the upper part and neutral or mildly alkaline in the lower part.
The A1 neutral hue, 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 3 through 5 dry, 2 or 3 moist, and chroma of 0 through 3.  It commonly is loam, but the range includes fine sandy loam and silt loam.  Rock fragments range from 10 to 15 percent stones, 20 to 30 percent cobbles, and 5 to 10 percent pebbles.
The A2 horizon has hue of 10YR through 5YR, value of 4 through 6 dry, 3 through 5 moist, and chroma of 2 through 4.  It is loam or fine sandy loam.  Rock fragments range from 10 to 20 percent stones, 20 to 30 percent cobbles, and 5 to 10 percent pebbles.
The B2t horizon has hue of 7.5YR through 2.5YR, value of 4 through 6 dry, 3 through 5 moist, and chroma of 4 through 6.  It is clay, silty clay or heavy clay loam.  Rock fragments are 0 to 10 percent stones, 0 to 5 percent cobbles, and 0 to 5 percent pebbles in the upper part and 5 to 10 percent stones, 3 to 15 percent cobbles, and 3 to 10 percent pebbles in the lower part.
The B3 horizon has hue of 7.5YR through 2.5YR, value of 5 or 6 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 4 through 6.  It is sandy clay loam, sandy clay, heavy loam, or clay loam.  Rock fragments range from 15 to 30 percent stones, 10 to 15 percent cobbles and heavy clay loam, and 10 to 15 percent pebbles.  Some pedons have C horizons.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Acel, Burnac, Dandrea, Iles and Siesta series.  Acel soils have carbonate accumulation at depth of 15 to 25 inches.  Burnac soils have a solum less than 40 inches thick.  Dandrea soils have a paralithic contact at a depth of 20 to 40 inches.  Iles soils have a carbonate accumulation at a depth of less than 40 inches.  Siesta soils are moderately alkaline and have cinders in the lower Bt horizon.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Spud soils are on gently sloping to extremely steep mountainsides.  The slope is commonly 20 to 50 percent, but ranges from 5 to 60 percent.  The soils formed in fine textured alluvial, colluvial, and residual material weathered from basalt with modification from underlying sandstone and shale.  Elevation is 8,000 to 10,000 feet.  The mean annual temperature is 40 to 45 degrees F.  The mean annual precipitation is 18 to 20 inches.  The frost free period is from 80 to 100 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Barela, Dalcan, Hillery, Raton, Saladon, Yankee, and the competing Burnac soils.  Barela, Hillery, Saladon, and Yankee soils have mollic epipedons.  Dalcan soils have a lithic contact at a depth of 21 to 40 inches.  Raton soils have a lithic contact at a depth of 6 to 20 inches.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium or rapid runoff; very slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Most areas of the Spud soils are used for commercial woodland, wildlife habitat, and recreation.  Vegetation is mainly Douglas fir, white fir, limber pine, aspen, Engelmann and blue spruce, and mountain grasses.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  The Spud soils are of moderate extent in northern New Mexico.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Mora County, New Mexico, 1981.
ADDITIONAL DATA:  Lab numbers 79P2012-2020.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U. S. A.
